Section 1 - Preparing for the assembly process

In this section you will be preparing your workspace, gathering the necessary tools, and preparing the printer components for assembly.

Note - There are many small pieces that are easy to lose, so we strongly recommend that you keep the parts in their bags until they are called for.

1. Find a large, clean, well lit surface to work on.
2. Make sure you have access to the following tools:
  • Utility knife
  • Small file with pointed corner
  • Ruler (metric or imperial)
  • Cyanoacrylate™ glue (CA glue, AKA superglue)
  • Needle nose pliers
  • permanent marker or pencil
  • Scotch tape
  • Wire cutters
  • Wire strippers
  • Flat head precision screwdriver
  • Small phillips head screwdriver

Section 2 - Testing the snap-fit mirror frame

Description: In this section you will be testing the snap-fitting action of the mirror frame and other components. It is important to gain an experience with how the printer snaps together before you actually begin the assembly process.
For this section you will need:
  • One of the Mirror Frames
  • Static damper mount B (Mirror frame mount B)
  • Spring force magnet holder (static magnet holder)

Click to see an image of the parts labelled.

1. Slide the Mirror Frame into the large side of the slot on the Spring Force Magnet Holder (Static Magnet Holder) so that the 1 arrows (1 →) are the same side and point at each other, then snap one side of the mirror frame into the narrow end of the slot, then snap the other side.
2. Clip Static Damper Mount B (Mirror frame mount B) to Mirror Frame B so that the 2 arrows (2 →) are on the same side and point at each other when snapped together.
3. Disassemble the parts you just assembled.

Section 3 - Assembling the Thread Assembly

Description: In this section you will be attaching the mirrors, magnets, and elastic thread to the a small plastic connector piece we call the acetate arrow. These components when put together make up the moving parts of the Peachy Printer’s galvonometers.
For this section you will need:
  • Elastic thread - Note: the thread is wrapped around the plastic syringe.
  • Carbon Rod
  • 2 Acetate Arrows - Note: This is a very small piece of plastic, there is no difference between the two arrows of the same colour, and your kit contains two sets of arrows (one clear one orange). The orange has yet to be tested, so only use it in the case that you lose the clear arrows.
  • The magnets (For this step we will be using the smaller magnets, but we find it is best to keep them stuck to the large magnets so they do not get lost.)
  • 2 Mirrors (Leave the protective film on the surface of the mirrors)
  • Metal tweezers
  • CA Glue
Click to see an image of the parts labelled.

1. Take the acetate arrow and fold the magnet tab to a 90 degree angle, either way.
2. Take 2 of the smaller magnets, and stack them, they will naturally want to do this.
3. Pinch the smaller magnets in between the tweezers tips. While doing so, use your fingernail to split the smaller magnets, making sure they are still aligned in a way they are attracted to each other, so that one magnet is on each tip of the tweezers.
4. Pinch the magnet tab between the magnets with the tweezers, slide the tweezers away while using your thumb and forefinger to hold the magnets in place. The magnets should remain on each side of the magnet tab, near the middle.
5. Put a small dab of CA glue onto the magnets so they are glued to the acetate arrow.
6. With the elastic thread, tie a knot (near the one end of the elastic thread) loosely so that there is a large loop, insert the carbon rod through the loop and then tighten the knot onto the rod. Once snug, pull on an end of the knot to make sure it will not come undone, if it does then re-tie it tighter.
7. Cut the short end of excess thread off about 1mm away from the carbon rod.
8. Cut the carbon rod to a length of about 4 mm, the knot should be in the middle of the piece you cut.
9. Cut the long end of the excess elastic thread to about 15 cm long (approximate).
10. Repeat steps 6 - 8 so you have 2 of these.
11. Put the elastic thread through the hole on one end of the acetate arrow so that the carbon rod is on the opposite face as the magnets.
12. Take the second piece of elastic thread and put it through the hole on the other end of the arrow, so the carbon rod is on the opposite face as the magnets. We will now call this a thread assembly.
13. Remove the film from the back of the mirror and place the mirror onto its mounting spot on the acetate arrow so it is on the same side as the magnets. We will now call this a thread assembly.

Note: This step has recently been re-ordered. This makes the photo out of date, but still useful.
14. Repeat steps 1-13 so that you have two thread assemblies.

Section 4 - Mounting the Thread Assemblies to the Mirror Frames

Description: In this section you’ll be mounting the thread assemblies to the mirror frames. The mirror frame is what connects the thread assemblies to the other components of the printer.

For this section you will need:
  • Both Thread Assemblies
  • Both Mirror Frames
  • Cyanoacrylate Glue
  • Utility Knife

Click to see an image of the parts labelled.

1. Lay the mirror assembly frame down so that the arrows are facing up. Then take and lay the thread assembly across the top of the frame with the side without the magnets butted up against the inside edge of the mirror assembly frame on the side with the opening.
2. Take the thread extending off the side of the thread assembly without the mirrors and lace it through the center notch on the edge of the mirror assembly frame, then lace the thread around the upper and lower notches multiple times to lock it in place. Make sure the acetate arrow is butted up against the mirror frame. Apply glue to the elastic thread where it wraps around the upper notch and then cut off the excess thread.

Note: The notches on the edges of the mirror frame may not be deep enough to lock the thread in place. If this is the case then carefully use a utility knife to cut the notches deeper.
3. Pinch the thread on the magnet side of the Thread Assembly and pull it across and into the center notch on the other edge of the Mirror Assembly frame. Ensure that the magnets are centered at the dashes in between the two mounting points on the outer edges of the mirror assembly frame.
4. Repeat the same process of wrapping the thread around the mirror assembly as shown in step 2. Cut off any excess thread. Once finished the thread assembly should rotate freely. Your mirror assembly should look like the last image ine the set.
5. Fold the dynamic damper plate out 90 degrees so that it protrudes to the side opposite of the magnets.
6. Remove the film from the back of the mirror and place the mirror onto its mounting spot on the acetate arrow so it is on the same side as the magnets. We will now refer to this as the Mirror Assembly.

Section 5 - Adding the Spring Force Magnets and Coils to the Mirror Assembly

Description: In this section you'll be assembling the spring force adjustment tubes, and mounting them along with the coils to the mirror assembly. The spring force adjustment tubes adjust the natural resting position (orientation) of the mirrors. The coils receive the signal coming from your computer's audio jack and drive the movement of the mirrors, completing the Peachy's galvonometers.
For this section you will need:
  • Clear tubing
  • Large square magnets
  • Coils
  • Both Mirror assemblies
  • Utility knife
  • Needle nose pliers
  • spring force mounting plate
  • permanent marker or pencil

Click to see an image of the parts labelled.

1. Insert the needle nosed pliers into the clear tubing while closed and then open them to stretch the opening of the tube.
2. Insert the square magnets into the stretched end of the clear tubing so that the north and south poles are sideways, touching the walls of the tubing. If you inserted the magnets in the correct orientation, they should attract to each other through the walls of the tubing.
3. Cut the clear tubing 3 cm (about 1") back from the stretched end.
4. Repeat steps 2 - 4 until you have four 3 cm tubes with magnets inside them. *If your magnets do not attract like this, they are not positioned correctly*. We will now call these the spring force adjustment tubes.
5. Clip the mirror frame into the Spring Force Mounting Plate as you did in Step 1 of Section 1.
6. Insert the non-magnet end of a spring force adjustment tube into the partial hole that extends off of the slot on the spring force mounting plate. Pull the tube through the hole until the magnet itself is right inside the hole. The excess tube must extend off of the mounting plate in the opposite direction of the mirror assembly.
7. Rotate the spring force adjustment tube until the face of the acetate arrow is level with the face of the mirror assembly frame. The dynamic damper arm must be extending away from the spring force adjustment tube.
8. Using a permanent marker, mark on the spring force adjustment tube the side that is closest to the thread assembly. Remove the spring force adjustment tube from the hole and glue the coil to the marked side centered directly on the magnet. Make sure that the coil is positioned so that the leads extend in the same direction as the excess tube coming off the magnet.
9. Insert the spring force adjustment tube and coil back into the hole on the spring force adjustment plate. It should look like the last picture in this step.
10. Insert another spring force adjustment tube into the second hole on the mounting plate. If necessary, rotate the adjustment tube so the face of the acetate arrow is parallel with the face of the mirror assembly frame.
11. Repeat steps 5-10 on the other mirror assembly.

Section 6 - Mounting the Mirror Assemblies to the L Bracket

Description: In this section you'll be mounting both mirror assemblies to the L bracket. The L bracket is the piece that holds the laser, the circuit, and the mirror assemblies together in one piece.
For this section you will need:
  • Both Mirror Assemblies
  • The L Bracket
  • Male and Female Static Damper Connectors (both sets)
  • Static damper mount B (Mirror frame mount B)
  • Cyanoacrylate glue
  • Utility Knife
  • Neon Tubing

Click to see an image of the parts labelled.

1. Cut two 1 cm (3/8") pieces from the neon tubing and split one wall of each tube all the way down the side in the center.
2. On the Static Damper Mount and the L Bracket, mount the neon tubes around the inside edges a of the narrow half of the Damper Slider Channel (the slot).
3. Apply glue to both sides of the tubes where it meets the plastic.
4. Clip Static Damper Mount B (Mirror frame mount B) to Mirror Frame B so that the 2 arrows (2 →) are on the same side and point at each other when snapped together.
5. Clip Mirror Frame A onto the center of the L bracket so that the 2 arrows (2 →) point at each other.
6. Clip Static Damper Mount B into the L bracket so that the 3 arrows (3 →) point at each other when snapped into place.

Section 7 - Assembling and Oiling the Static Dampers

Description: In this section you'll be assembling, mounting, and applying oil to the dampening system. The dampening system reduces the impact of vibrations on the printer caused by movements in the room during a print. The static dampers are small adjustable plastic pieces that get mounted in very close proximity to the dynamic dampers. A small drop of oil is placed in between the static and dynamic dampers, bridging the gap between the two parts and preventing most vibrations from effecting the precise movement of the galvonometers. Dampening is an essential part of the Peachys hardware, without it prints would often fail and rarely look good.

Note: Due to the fact that the dynamic damper tab is a protruding and moving part, and that the static damper must be mounted in such close proximity for the dampening system to work, it can often be the source of malfunction if it's not adjusted properly. If during calibration or printing later on you notice that one of the galvonometers stops moving, it is likely that the dynamic damper tab is running into the static damper and needs to be re-adjusted.
For this section you will need:
  • Male Static Damper Connector
  • Female Damper Connector
  • The L bracket with both mirror assemblies mounted.
  • Oil dripper
  • Carbon rod (leftover from making thread assemblies)

Click to see an image of the parts labelled.

1. Take a Male Static Damper Connector and insert it into the slider channel in the L bracket so that the male end points toward the Spring force magnet holder (static magnet holder)
2. Clip the Female Damper Connector onto the Male Damper Connector so that the acetate arrow is inside the arch on the Female Damper Connector.
3. Take a Male Static Damper Connector and insert it into the slider channel in the Static damper mount B (Mirror frame mount B) so that the male end points toward the Spring force magnet holder (static magnet holder)
4. Clip the Female Damper Connector onto the Male Damper Connector so that the acetate arrow is inside the arch on the Female Damper Connector.
5. Make sure the Dynamic Damper Tab is lifted on the acetate arrow and pointing up at 90 degrees.
6. Adjust the Female Damper Connector so that it is almost touching the Dynamic damper tab on the acetate arrow (less than 1mm away, but not touching it).
7. Using the carbon rod apply a very small dab of oil in between each of the Female Static Damper Connectors and the Dynamic Dampers, making sure not to drip oil elsewhere on your printer.

Section 8 - Making the laser focus adjustable

Description: In this section you will be taking apart the laser, adding an aperture disc, and ensuring that the lasers focus ring can indeed adjust the focus.

Unfortunately, due to the design of the lasers we ordered, the focus ring must be glued to the threaded lens housing to lock it in place. If this is not done, the focus ring will often just spin on the threaded lens housing rather than gripping it and spinning the lens housing further into or out of the laser body itself.

Adding an aperture limits the amount of light and the size of the beam leaving the laser allowing us to print thin and properly cured walls.

Note: There are no images for this section yet.
For this section you will need:
  • Laser
  • Needle nose pliers
  • The Laser Aperture Disc
  • Pin
  • Carbon rod (for a glue stick)
  • CA Glue

Click to see an image of the parts labelled.

1. Take your laser and remove the focus ring (the notched silver ring on the end) from the laser.
2. Take the needle nose pliers and remove the threaded lens housing (the black ring that the focus ring threads on to) from the laser.
3. Very carefully use a piece of carbon rod to dab glue around the edge of the threaded lens housing. Be sure that you don’t get any glue on the lens itself. Place the laser aperture disc on top of the threaded lens housing so that it's centered over the lens. Allow the glue to dry before continuing.
4. Use the pin to poke a hole directly in the center of the aperture disc.
5. Screw the focus ring on no more than one full turn. Apply glue to the point where the focus ring meets the threaded lens housing, securing the focus ring in place. Allow the glue to dry before continuing.

Note: If the focus ring gets turned onto the threaded lens housing too far it will eliminate a portion of the lens travel distance necessary to achieve infinity focus.
6. Screw the threaded lens housing and focus ring back into the laser body.

Section 9 - Mounting the Laser to the L bracket

Description: In this section you'll be mounting the laser to the L bracket and making the laser focusing system. Laser Bracket A will grip the focus ring of the laser so that you can adjust its focus by turning the body of the laser. This allows you to easily adjust the focus without removing the laser from the printer. Together, the laser mounting brackets hold the laser to the L bracket and ensure that the laser beam is directed at the first of the two mirrors.
For this section you will need:
  • The Laser
  • Laser Bracket A and B
  • L Bracket
  • Neon Tubing
  • Utility Knife

Click to see an image of the parts labelled.

1. Take a piece of neon tubing and cut it so it is 4cm.
2. Stand the neon tubing on its end and use a sharp knife to split one wall of the neon tubing down the center.
3. Take the neon tubing and slide it onto the inside edge of the ring on Laser Bracket A so that the slit on the tube hugs both sides of the plastic.
4. Slide Laser Bracket A onto the L Bracket so that the arrows ( → ) in arrow set number 4 point at each other.
5. Slide Laser Bracket B onto the L Bracket. so that the arrows ( → ) in arrow set number 4B point at each other.
6. Insert the laser through the hole in Laser Bracket B, so the Focus Ring is being held by the Neon Tubing on Laser Bracket A.

Section 10 - Mounting the Circuit

Description: In this section you'll be attaching the circuit to its mounting plate, which in turn clips onto the L bracket. The circuit mounting plate, along with the stand off also connects the L bracket to the main hanger (the piece that mounts the printer to its housing).
For this section you will need:
  • Circuit
  • Circuit mounting plate
  • The L Bracket with Mirror Assemblies and Laser attached
  • The Stand off
  • 4 small bolts
  • 4 small nuts
  • small phillips head screwdriver

Click to see an image of the parts labelled.

1. Hold the Circuit Mounting Plate so that the etchings are face down and and the arrow is pointing to the right. Then put the circuit down on top of the mounting plate so that the audio jack is positioned overtop of the arrow.
2. Insert 4 small bolts into each hole on the Circuit so they go through the Circuit Mount.
3. Thread the nuts onto the bolts so the Circuit is held on tightly. Note: The head of the bolts should be on the Circuit's) (side), the nuts on the Circuit's) Mount (side).
4. Insert the circuit mounting plate onto the slot on the L Bracket so that arrow 5 points directly at the 5 on the snapping nub of the circuit mounting plate.
5. Insert the Stand off arm into the L bracket so that arrow 6 points directly at the 6 on the snapping nub of the Stand off arm.

Section 11 - Hooking the Coils up to the Circuit

Description: In this section you'll be wiring the coil leads into the screw terminals on the circuit board. There is no soldering required, however if you are comfortable with soldering and would like to do so, it will provide you with a more reliable connection.

Note: Some of the images in this section are missing.
For this section you will need:
  • Coils
  • Insulated wire
  • The small sand paper square or a lighter
  • Precision flat head screwdriver
  • Wire cutters
  • Wire strippers

Click to see an image of the parts labelled.

1. Take the piece of insulated wire and cut three pieces to a length of 12mm. Strip one end of each piece of wire back half way. Set the pieces of stripped wire aside.
2-A. Take the coil leads and sand the coating off 1" back from the end of both wires. Sand gently about 25 strokes covering all "sides" of the wire while being careful not to break the wire.
2-B. Take the coils leads and heat the end (1 ") of both wires with a lighter so that the coating is removed. Be careful not to hold the flame too close, as it will melt the wire.
3. Take one lead wire off each coil and twist an inch of each of them around each other.
4. Take the 2 coil wires you just twisted together, and wrap them around the stripped wire.
5. Insert the stripped wire with the connected coil leads wrapped around it into Port 2 on the circuit, so that the coil wires are inserted into the port.
6. Take the other lead wire of one of the coils and wrap it around another stripped wire.
7. Repeat step 4 with the second coil on its own stripped wire.
8. Take one of the stripped wires with a single coil lead wire wrapped around it and insert it into port 1, so the coil wire itself is inserted inside the port.
9. Take the other stripped with with a coil lead wire wrapped around it and insert it into Port 3 so the coil wire itself is inserted inside the port.

Section 12 - Assembling the safety switch

Description: In this section you'll be assembling and wiring the safety switch and the laser. The safety switch will disable the laser if the outer protective housing is removed, or if the printer gets tipped over. This adds yet another layer of safety to the Peachy Printer.
For this section you will need:
  • The Main Hanger
  • 4 Small Bolts
  • 4 Small Nuts
  • Insulated wire
  • Aluminum Foil
  • Acetate Pants
  • Clear Tape (Scotch tape)

Click to see an image of the parts labelled.

1. First we will make the Safety Switch Plate. Take the Acetate Pants and gently fold them making a shallow crease that continues the pre cut line at the end of the plastic. The crease should only go halfway up the pants, not all the way to the other end.
2. Push each leg of the acetate pants together slightly so their is a slight overlap, and tape it. It should make a shallow valley between the legs of the pants.
3. Tape a piece of Aluminum Foil to the inside of the valley covering the slit in the pants that you just taped. Leaving at least 3 inches (6.5cm) of extra Aluminum Foil extending off the edge without the holes in it.
4. Fold the extra Aluminum Foil around the underside of the valley and to the end of the pants so that it is covering the 2 holes.
5. Carefully poke a hole in the Aluminum Foil where the holes in the acetate pants are. We will now call this the safety switch plate.
6. Insert a small bolt in each hole in the safety switch plate so the head is sitting on the valley side of the Aluminum Foil. Cut away any extra Aluminum Foil. You can now set the safety switch plate aside.
7. Take the piece of wire and cut it so you have 2 wires that are each 18 cm (10 inches) long.
8. Strip 8 cm off of one end of one wire, and 1 cm (3/8 inch) off the other end of the same wire.
9. Strip 2 cm (3/4 inch) off of one end of the other wire, and 1 cm (3/8 inch) off the other end of the same wire.
10. Take the Main Hanger and insert one bolt into each of the holes on the side of the safety switch plate. Ensure that the bolt heads are sitting on the face opposite to the etchings.
11. Take the wire with the longest stripped end. Wrap the long striped piece of wire around the one of the bolts on the Main Hanger, then run it across the channel and wrap it around the bolt on the other side. Screw a nut onto each bolt, clamping the wire in place. Make sure the wire is mounted to the same side of the Main Hanger as the labelling.
12. Mount the safety switch plate to the main hanger by sticking the two bolts into the two closely spaced holes in the main hanger.

Note: You should insert the bolts into the main hanger from the side opposite of the etchings.

Thread a nut onto one of the bolts tightening the safety switch in place.
13. Take the second wire (the 18cm wire with 1 cm of wire cut off one end and 2cm off the other) and wrap the longer stripped end around the other bolt on the safety switch plate, then screw a nut onto the bolt, pinching the wire into place. You should now have one remaining stripped end on each safety switch wire.
14. Strip about 5mm of the ends of both laser wires.
15. Take the end of a safety switch wire and wrap it around the bare end of one of the wires coming from the laser. Repeat this with the other safety switch wire, connecting it to the other laser wire. It does not matter which safety switch wire gets connected to which laser wire.
16. Insert the ground (black) wire end (with the other wire wrapped around it) into Port 5 on the circuit.

Note: There is one more step to do before the laser and safety switch are completely hooked up. We are leaving it incomplete at this point to ensure that there is no risk of the laser turning on while unguarded. The laser and safety switch will be completed in a later section.

Section 13 - Mounting the Laser Assembly to the Main Hanger

Description: In this step you'll be mounting the laser assembly to the main hanger. The main hanger is what connects the internal workings of the printer to the internal housing.
For this section you will need:
  • The Main hanger
  • The Laser assembly (The L bracket with the Circuit, Laser, and Mirror assemblies mounted.)
  • Stand Off
  • Tweezers

Click to see an image of the parts labelled.

1. Connect the Laser Assembly to the Main Hanger by inserting the Stand off arm and Circuit Mounting Plate into mounting slots 7 and 8 respectively. The 7 on the Circuit Mounting Plate should be facing the 7 on the Main Hanger, and the 8 on the Stand off arm should be facing the 8 on the Main Hanger.
2. Use tweezers to remove the protective film from the reflective side of the mirror. Be very careful not to touch the mirror with your fingers.

Section 14 - Assembling the Internal Box

Description: In this section you'll be assembling the internal housing. It serves as a mounting stand for the inner workings of the Peachy Printer.


    Note: The images for this section are very out of date, and many are missing. You'll notice that the internal housing is made of cardboard, and is glued together. This is of course no longer the case, however we left the images in as the pieces are still similar in other ways, and should be helpful regardless.
For this section you will need:
  • The 3 Internal housing pieces (these will look similar to the external housing pieces, but - they are slightly smaller and have one tab on each piece)
  • The Main Hanger with Laser Assembly attached
  • Black duct tape (this is a temporary solution and will snap together in the future, duct tape is included in your kit)

Click to see an image of the parts labelled.

1. Cut eight, 2 inch long sections of black duct tape. Stick them to the edge of your table for later.
2. Take the widest of the 3 internal housing pieces and lay it down on your workspace so that the smooth side is facing up and the tab is at the top.
3. Place one piece of tape on each of the 4 corners so that half of each piece of tape is hanging off the side edges.
4. Stand the piece on it's bottom edge so that the tab is pointing up. Rotate it 180 degrees so that the rough side of the plastic is facing towards you. This is going to be the back wall of the internal housing.
5. With your free hand grab one of the other internal housing pieces and butt it's edge up against the front face of the back wall so that the rough side is facing inward, and the tab is pointing up and closest to the front edge.
6. Fold the extra tape sticking out off the back wall around the corner and onto the sidewall. Do this on both the top and the bottom pieces of tape. The two walls should now stand on their own.
7. Take the third and final internal housing piece and repeat steps 5 & 6. The internal housing should stand upright with the two side walls extending out at a 90 degree angle from the back wall, all the rough sides should be facing inwards, the tabs should be pointing up, and the two tabs on the sidewalls should be nearest the front edge.
8. Take the main hanger with the laser assembly attached and place it on top the internal housing so that the 3 tabs on the internal housing go through the 3 slots on the main hanger.

Section 15 - Assembling the External Housing

Description: In this section you'll be assembling the external housing. This external housing has a UV filtering see-through face, providing yet another layer of safety while still allowing you to observe what the printer is doing. It also hangs the steel ball that sits on and activates the safety switch.

Note: The some of the images for this section are very out of date, and many are missing. You'll notice that the internal housing is made of cardboard, and is glued together. This is of course no longer the case, however we left the images in as the pieces are still similar in other ways, and should be helpful regardless.
For this section you will need:
  • The 3 External Housing Pieces (these will look similar to the internal housing pieces that were used in the previous step, but they are larger and have no tabs)
  • The Internal Housing you assmebled in Step 14.
  • Elastic Thread
  • The Steel Ball
  • The large Orange Sheet
  • Clear Tape (Scotch Tape)
  • Cyanoacrylate glue (CA glue AKA superglue)
  • Black duct tape (this is a temporary solution and will snap together in the future, duct tape is included in your kit)

Click to see an image of the parts labelled.

1. Take the widest of the 3 external housing pieces and lay it down on your workspace so that the rough side is facing up.
2. Place one piece of tape on each of the 4 corners so that half of each piece of tape is hanging off the side edges.
3. Stand the piece on it's edge. Rotate it 180 degrees so that the smooth side of the plastic is facing towards you. This is going to be the back wall of the external housing.
4. With your free hand grab one of the other external housing pieces and butt it’s edge up against the front face of the back wall so that the smooth side is facing inward, and the channel is on the bottom edge and closest to the front.
5. Fold the extra tape sticking out off the back wall around the corner and onto the sidewall. Do this on both the top and the bottom pieces of tape. The two walls should now stand on their own.
6. Take the third and final external housing piece and repeat steps 4 & 5. The external housing should stand upright with the two side walls extending out at a 90 degree angle from the back wall, all the smooth sides should be facing inwards, and the two channels on the sidewalls should be on the bottom edge nearest the front.
7. Use CA glue to glue the steel ball to the end of 3 inches of elastic thread.
8. Put the elastic thread through the hole in the Orange Sheet so that the Steel Ball is on the inside of the existing fold, and tape the elastic thread so that the ball is hanging about 1 inch from the orange sheet. Cut off the excess elastic thread.

Note: This is a very small hole, just large enough for the thread to go through. If the whole isn't big enough, poke it with the leftover carbon rod or something of similar size.
9. Fold the Orange Sheet along the dotted lines around the outer edges, so that the folds point to the inside angle of the pre-existing fold.
10. Take the orange plastic sheet and use the extra black duct tape to tape the edges you folded in the previous step to the inside walls of the external housing so that it closes the top and front faces of the box. Your steel ball should be hanging from the back right corner of the box.
11. Slide the Outer housing over the Inner housing.
12. Now test the safety switch, first make sure the safety switch is not touching the wire beneath when the steel ball is not on top of it.
13. Tip and shake the external housing, the steel ball should fall off the switch long before the printer tips to an angle where the laser could shine out of the housing.

Section 16 - Assembling the Drip system

Description: In this section you'll be assembling the drip system. The drip system uses a siphoning action to drip saltwater from the top reservoir into the bottom reservoir raising the height of the resin. The microphone cables will be hooked up to the pieces of aluminum rod so it can detect when a drip occurs. By counting the number of drips the Peachy Printer is able to know what height the resin is currently at, so it knows what layer to print.

Recommendation: If using our standard setup, we recommend using a lower reservoir with a maximum height of 6 cm. If you can’t find anything of that size, cutting the bottom of an empty and clean milk or cream container to that height is an easy solution. While we realize that our recommendation provides you with a very small build volume, we strongly suggest that you use it as a starting point. Using a standard system make troubleshooting much easier. In addition, We've yet to test large prints. For that reason it's a good idea to start with what we know works, and right now that is prints less than 4 cm tall.

Note: You must choose reservoirs that have the same distance from wall to wall all the way up (walls that are not tapered). If the reservoir is larger at the top than it is at the bottom, larger at the bottom than it is at the top, or larger in the middle than it is at the top or bottom it will not work.

You also must make sure that your upper reservoir is no larger than your lower reservoir. In fact, it’s best if it is somewhat smaller to ensure that your lower reservoir will never overflow.
For this section you will need:
  • Clear Tubing - Note: If you need more clear tubing for your custom setup you can buy it from most pet stores (it's airline tubing for aquariums).
  • Neon Tubing - Note: If you need more neon tubing for your custom setup you can buy it from most hobby stores (it's Nitro RC fuel line).
  • Syringe
  • 3 Clamp Rings
  • 3 Larger Bolts (they fit into the clamp rings)
  • 2 Nuts
  • Top Piece
  • Hose Hanger
  • Needle nose pliers with wire cutter
  • Wire stripper
  • Small file (must have sharp angle for precision filing)
  • The small sandpaper square or a lighter
  • Hollow Aluminum Rod
  • Audio Cable
  • Upper and Lower liquid reservoirs

Click to see an image of the parts labelled.

1. Take the Hollow Aluminum Rod and cut it in half using the wire cutter on the needle nose pliers. Use the end of the needle nose pliers to pinch one end shut. Then make sure the other three remain open.
2. Take the rod with the closed end and file the points on both creased edges of the closed end. Once finished, the closed end should be no wider than the rest of the rod.
3. Take the rod with the closed end and file nearly halfway through the aluminum rod creating a small hole positioned in the middle of the rod. Be careful not to bend the rod.
4. Disassemble the syringe. take the black plunger gasket and poke a hole (smaller than the aluminum rod) in the center of the peak.
5. Cut four 1 cm pieces of neon tubing. Take one and insert it into the plunger, put the others aside for now.
6. Take the Rod with 2 open ends and push it through the Neon Tubing and the Plunger so the Plunger is near the middle of the Rod.
7. Insert the Rod and Plunger into the large opening of the syringe.
8. Take the Rod with a closed end and push the closed end into the small hole. (where a needle normally goes) You might need to file the edges of the aluminum rod more to get it to fit into the syringe, but make sure it is still closed. The hole you filed in the side must be inside the syringe. Water needs to flow through this hole from within the syringe so it must not be blocked.
9. Take a second piece of 1 cm neon tubing and slide it onto the excess aluminum tube that is extending from the bottom hole in the syringe. Push it all the way up so that it climbs over and covers the end of the syringe.
10. Take the Audio Jack and cut off one end, then strip about 4 inches off the end. Cut off the insulating thread.
11. Burn or sand off the protective coating on the ends of all three wires, being careful not to melt the wires.
12. Twist the red and blue wires together.
13. Take the red and blue wires and wrap it around one of the larger bolts, right near the head. Thread a nut all the way onto the bolt till it snugly clamps the wire in place.
14. Repeat step 13 with the remaining wire from the audio cable and another bolt/nut.
15. Take two clamp rings and thread one onto each of the bolts just a couple of turns.
16. Take your Syringe and push the rod with the rubber plunger in until it just barely touches the other aluminum rod.
17. Take both of the Clamp Rings (with wires) and clamp one on each end of the aluminum rods extending out of the top and bottom ends of the syringe. It does not matter which clamp goes on which end. Be very careful not to crush the aluminum rod by over tightening the clamp.
18. Take another 1cm piece neon tubing and put it on the rod coming out of the bottom of the syringe, so it buts up against the Clamp Ring.
19. Cut a two 10 cm pieces of neon tubing. Take one of them and make an angle cut on the end of the hose so that a Clamp ring can be slid over it. Use the pliers to pull the neon tubing through the clamp ring 1 cm beyond the angle cut. Then trim off the angle piece leaving at least 1 cm of neon tubing.
20. Apply glue all the way around the outer edge of the Hose Hanger and glue it to the middle of the neon tubing with the clamp on it. It’s important that the hose is glued well enough that it follows the curve of the Hose Hanger.

Tip: We found that glueing a large straw (larger than the clear tubing) up one wall of your reservoirs very well as an alternative, then you can simply slip the tubing into the straw and not have to worry about it falling out or not reaching near the bottom of the reservoir. This method may replace, or be used in combination with the hose hangers.
21. Move the clamp so that it is at the end of the Hose Hanger.
22. Repeat step 20 with the remaining 10cm piece of tubing so that you have another hose hanger (this one doesn't need a clamp).
23. Slide the end of the neon tube with the clamp on it onto the aluminum rod sticking out of the top of the syringe. Be sure their is space between the rod in the tube, and where the O clamp on the neon tube starts, so the O clamp does not pinch the rod inside the tube.
24. Take the outer housing off of your printer and slide your lower reservoir into the internal housing so that it sits directly below the laser assembly.
25. You must now cut two sections of clear hose to make each end of your drip system reach into the upper and lower reservoirs. If you are sticking with our default printer setup, then follow step 26-A. If you are making your own custom reservoir setup, Follow step 26-B.
27-A. Put your outer housing back on (the drip feed hose should exit through the side of the outer housing where the notch is cut). Put the upper cardboard plate on the External housing, then place your upper reservoir on top. Place the hose hanger on the edge of your upper reservoir so that the drip feed is hanging down the outside of it.
28-A. Measure the distance between the end of the neon tube on the hose hanger to the bottom of your upper reservoir. Cut a piece of clear tubing to that length, stretch one end of it with your pliers and then slide it onto the neon tube on the end of the hose hanger (you may want to remove the hose hanger from the upper reservoir to connect the clear tubing).
29-A. You may now hang your drip feed from the upper reservoir (the clear tubing you just connected should reach the bottom of the upper reservoir).
26-B. The length of these clear tubing sections will depend on the size of your upper and lower reservoirs, as well as the total distance between the two reservoirs. Cut them to the appropriate length and then slide the two pieces of clear tubing over the neon tubing at the top and bottom of your drip feed.
27-B. You can now hang the top end of your drip feed in the upper reservoir, letting the drip feed run down into the lower reservoir. We recommend securing your drip feed to something solid on at least one point.

Congratulations, you've assembled the Peachy Printer!

Section 17 - Installing the software

Description: In this section you'll be downloading and installing the Peachy Printer software. Scroll down to find the instructions for your operating system.

Note: At this point installing the software must currently be done from source. The next major release is in progress and will work like a normal application. If you are unfamiliar with running commands in from the terminal, we've found some tutorials that will help you understand how to complete this section. Select the tutorial for your operating system.

Windows: http://www.computerhope.com/issues/chusedos.htm

Mac: http://mac.appstorm.net/how-to/utilities-how-to/how-to-use-terminal-the-basics/

Linux: https://help.ubuntu.com/community/UsingTheTerminal
For this section you will need:
  • A computer - Note: We recommend that you choose one computer to print with at all times. If you ever want to switch computers, you will have to re-tune your circuit and re-calibrate the printer.
  • An internet connection

Installing the software in Windows

1. Install Python

A. Vist the website "http://python.org/download/". From the list of options choose the "Python 2.7.6 Windows Installer" and follow the links to download the file
B. Once the file has downloaded double click it to run the installer
C. Follow the installer steps choose the default options
2. Add Python to the windows command line

A. While holding down the windows key press the r key, this opens the run dialogue. Type in cmd and press Enter This will open the command prompt (white text on a black screen)
B. In the command prompt window type setx PYTHON_HOME "C:\PYTHON27" and press Enter
C. On the next line type setx PATH "%PATH%;%PYTHON_HOME%;%PYTHON_HOME%\Scripts\" and press Enter
D. Type python --version and press Enter If you see the text Python 2.7.8 or similar, python is correctly installed. Type exit and press Enter to close the command prompt
3. Install Pyside - A python extension

A. Vist the website http://qt-project.org/wiki/PySide_Binaries_windows. Select the option "PySide-1.2.1.win32-py2.7.exe" and download the file
B. Once the file is downloaded double click it and follow the install procedures default setup
4. Install PyAudio - A python extension

A. Visit the website http://people.csail.mit.edu/hubert/pyaudio/#downloads
B. Select the "PyAudio for Python 2.7" option and download the file
C. Once the file is downloaded double click the file and follow the install procedures default setup
5. Install Numpy - A python extension

A. Vist the website http://sourceforge.net/projects/numpy/files/NumPy/1.8.0/numpy-1.8.0-win32-superpack-python2.7.exe/download to download the numpy installer
B. Once the file is downloaded double click the file and follow the install procedure default setup
6. Get the Peachy Printer Tools

A. Visit the website http://software.peachyprinter.com and download the latest version for your OS
B. Once you have downloaded the software open your download folder
Right click on the downloaded file and choose the option expand
D. Move the expanded folder to a place you will remember

Installing the software in Mac OSX

1. Install xcode-select - Code tools for Mac

A. Open the terminal application
B. At the terminal window type xcode-select --install and press Enter
C. Follow the on screen prompts to install with default options
2. Install Homebrew - A mac package manager

A. Open the terminal or use the same window as the previous step
B. At the terminal window type ruby -e "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.github.com/Homebrew/homebrew/go/install)" and press Enter
3. Install packages

A. Open the terminal or use the same window as the previous step
B. At the terminal window type brew install python pyside pyside-tools and press Enter - this process can take some time
C. At the terminal window type pip install numpy and press Enter - this process can take some time
4. Install Pyaudio - a python extension

A. Visit the website http://people.csail.mit.edu/hubert/pyaudio/packages/pyaudio-0.2.7.dmg to download pyaudio
B. Once the file is downloaded double click to open
C. Right click the installer and while holding down the option key left click the open option
D. On the warning dialogue click open
E. Follow the install procedures default setup
5. Get the Peachy Printer Tools

A. Visit the website http://software.peachyprinter.com and download the latest version for your OS
B. Once you have downloaded the software open your download folder
C. Right click on the downloaded file and choose the option expand
D. Move the expanded folder to a place you will remember

Installing the software in Linux (Debian)

1. Open the terminal
2. In the terminal type sudo apt-get -y install python-numpy python-pyaudio python-PySide and press Enter
3. Get the Peachy Printer Tools

A. Visit the website http://software.peachyprinter.com and download the latest version for your OS
B. Once you have downloaded the software open your download folder
C. Right click on the downloaded file and choose the option expand
D. Move the expanded folder to a place you will remember

Installing the software in Linux (Redhat)

1. Open the terminal
2. In the terminal type sudo yum -y install python-numpy python-pyaudio python-PySide and press Enter
3. Get the Peachy Printer Tools

A. Visit the website http://software.peachyprinter.com and download the latest version for your OS
B. Once you have downloaded the software open your download folder
C. Right click on the downloaded file and choose the option expand
D. Move the expanded folder to a place you will remember

Section 18 - Preparing for Calibration

Description: In this section you will be preparing to calibrate and tune your Peachy Printer. You will test to make sure your mirror assemblies are moving, you will mix up your saltwater solution and make a print base.

Note: There are no images for this section yet.
For this section you will need:
  • The two power cables
  • The Audio cable
  • The Peachy Printer
  • A computer (with software installed)
  • Wire mesh
  • Water
  • Large measuring cup
  • Box of salt
  • Safety glasses

Click to see an image of the parts labelled.

Safety Note: From this section on, you must wear your safety glasses at all times.

1. Put your safety glasses on. Remove the external housing, and dismount the main hanger from the internal housing. Set it down on the main hanger.
2. Insert the red wire coming out of the back of the laser into Port 4 on the circuit.
3. Mount the main hanger back onto the internal housing. Connect the 2 power cables and the Audio jack to the ports on the circuit of the printer. Run them down and out the side. Place the calibration grid inside the Internal Housing directly beneath the Main Hanger. When you place the external housing back on, your cables should exit through the small notch cut at the bottom of the external housing.

Note: It is best to use the standard USB ports on your computer, or a USB wall charger (for cellphones) to provide power to the printer. These options are the most reliable power sources. Stay away from USB hubs (unless plug into the wall) and USB ports on external monitors.
4. Ensuring that you're wearing the safety glasses, navigate to where-you-saved-the-software/peachyprintertools/src and run calibrate-main.py

Note: If it doesn't open for you by double clicking, you may have to right click > open with python launcher. You can also open it from the terminal. To do that, cd (change directory) into the src folder of peachyprintertools and then type python calibrate-main.py and press Enter
5. From the "shape" pull down menu, check that it is playing the "square" signal, and that laser power is checked to “on”. Take a close look at the mirrors, both mirrors should be slowly moving back and forth. You should be able to see the laser beam moving around on the surface of your work area (it may not look like a true square yet but we will get to that later). If all these things are happening, well done! This is a good sign your printer is working correctly. If not, please go back to sections 11 and 12 to ensure that you've wired the coils, laser, and safety switch properly. If you don't find the problem there, visit the beta tester forum for troubleshooting.

Note: The Peachy Printer Team is on our beta tester forum ready to help, and since you’ve made it this far there might be other people who could use your help to!
6. Take your leftover clear hose and cut three pieces to a length of 2 cm. Insert the 3 tubes into the square hole in the wire mesh (as if they are legs of a tripod). This will be the base from which you print off of. Set your print base aside.

Note: You will want these pieces of hose to be as close to the same size as each other as possible so that your platform is even and does not wobble. Don't use a 4 leg system as it is much more prone to wobbling, and may result in failed prints.
7. Mix your saltwater solution with 3 parts water and 1 part salt. Stir until it is completely dissolved. Set the saltwater aside.

Note: In an ideal mixture the water should be almost completely saturated with salt, and the resin should easily float on top of it.

Recommendation: We recommend making some extra salt water and keeping it in a resealable container. If you don’t have a resealable container then we recommend that you come back to this step when you get to Section 20, Part B - Calibrating the Drip Feed.

Section 19 - Tuning the Circuit

Description: In this section we will adjust the circuit so that when it receives a "zero" signal from your computer, it in turn sends 0.0 volts to the coils. As you will see we have some specific adjustment spots on the circuit for this purpose.

Note: If you start using a different computer to drive the printer after tuning the circuit, you will have to re-tune the circuit to the new computer.

Note: There are no images for this section yet.
For this section you will need:
  • The Peachy Printer with all cables connected to your computer and software installed
  • A precision flathead screwdriver
  • Voltmeter (optional)


Click to see an image of the parts labelled.

Note: If you don’t have a voltmeter follow instruction set A, if you do have a voltmeter follow instruction set B (further down).

Instruction Set A - Without a Voltmeter

1A. Unplug the two cables going to the USB ports on your computer.
2A. Remove the external housing, unmount the printer from the internal box, and set it down on the table. Disconnect the laser from the circuit before starting to avoid the hazards of the laser turning on. Connect the printer to your computer with the two power cables going to your computers USB ports, and the audio cable going to your computers headphone jack.
3A. Launch calibrate-main.py
4A. In the "shape: pull down menu change the shape to "center". Pull the audio jack out of your computer to check that the software is playing a signal. You should hear a high pitched tone, if so then plug the audio cable back in.
5A. Open your computer's advanced volume settings. Ensure that the master volume is at 100% and that the individual program volume for the calibration app is at 100% as well.

Note: Make sure that you never use gain. Every time you use your printer, the volume settings must be the same as they were when you calibrated.
6A. Remove the coil lead from screw terminal 1 on the circuit, trace the lead back to the mirror assembly it comes from. Take a look at the mirror on that assembly and make note of its natural resting position. The surface of the mirror should be level with the surface of the mirror frame (if it's not you'll have to adjust it with the spring force adjustment tube).

Tip: Looking at a reference point in the reflection of the mirror before reconnecting the lead is a great way to tell how far the mirror moves when the coil gets power, and to see if you've adjusted it back to it's natural resting position.
7A. Reconnect the coil lead to screw terminal 1, then adjust VR1 until the mirror is in it's natural resting position (the same position it was when the lead was not connected).

Note: If adjusted perfectly, the mirror should not move at all when you momentarily make a connection by tapping the coil lead to screw terminal 1. The more the mirror jumps the further it is away from being zeroed, so get it as close as you can (it doesn’t have to be perfect, but it shouldn't move much). When a printer's circuit is not zeroed to that specific computer, it may turn the laser off for a portion of it's path during a print, or the laser may never come on at all.
8A. Repeat with screw terminal 3, the other mirror assembly, and VR2.

Instruction set B - with a voltmeter

1B. Unplug the two cables going to the USB ports on your computer.
2B. Remove the external housing, unmount the printer from the internal box, and set it down on the table. Disconnect the laser from the circuit before starting to avoid the hazards of the laser turning on. Connect the printer to your computer with the two power cables going to your computer's USB ports, and the audio cable going to your computer’s headphone jack.
3B. Launch calibrate.py
4B. In the “shape: pull down menu change the shape to “center”. Pull the audio jack out of your computer to check that the software is playing a signal. You should hear a high pitched tone, if so then plug the audio cable back in.
5B. Open your computer’s advanced volume settings. Ensure that the master volume is at 100% and that the individual program volume for the calibration app is at 100% as well.

Note: Make sure you never have your volume over 100%, this should ensure that you’re not using gain in your sound system. Using gain will likely cause clipping of the audio signal that gets sent to the printer. This will result in a print that is missing an entire portion of it’s wall. Every time you use your printer, the volume settings must be the same.
6B. Set your voltmeter to the 2 volt range (unless autoranging).

Note: you might need to start on a higher range and then switch down to for more accuracy 2v.
7B. Connect the black lead of your voltmeter to Test Point TP12 - you'll have to hold it here for the rest of this section.
8B. Connect the red lead of your voltmeter to Test Point TP5. Adjust VR1 until the voltmeter reads in range between 0.000V - 0.050V. The closer you can get to 0.000V the better. VR1 and TP5 effect screw terminal 1.

Note: VR1 & 2 are 20 turn pots. That means they make 20 full rotations between their highest and lowest resistances. It is normal to turn the pot 5 times or more and see no change in voltage. Keep turning, once you get in range the voltage will change quickly.
9B. Move the red lead to Test Point TP6. Adjust VR2 until the voltmeter reads in range between 0.000V - 0.050V. Note: The closer you can get to 0.000V the better. VR2 and TP6 effect screw terminal 3.

Section 20 - Calibrating the Peachy Printer

For this section you will need:
  • The Peachy Printer with all connected to your computer with software installed, your upper and lower reservoirs, and the drip feed
  • Calibration grid
  • Extra elastic thread (about 9 inches in length)
  • One small nut (from the nuts and bolts bag)
  • Wire mesh print base
  • Saltwater
  • The extra syringe
  • Safety glasses


Click to see an image of the parts labelled.

Safety Note: This section of the instructions requires the laser to be on and unguarded. Everyone within line of sight of the printer should be wearing the UV protective glasses provided. If you have pets, make sure they are out of the room. Remember, you can't see the UV light very well. Even a very bright UV light will appear fairly dim to the human eye unless its shining on a phosphorescent surface.

Part A - Calibrating the printer

Description: Calibrating your printer will help account for discrepancies in centering, distance from the print area, and physical differences between each printer. This process is required every time you change the printer height, change reservoirs, move the internal components of the printer (such as a hard bump or a fall), change computers, or change sound cards.

Note: This section has no images yet.
1A. Determine the height of your lower reservoir by measuring from the bottom of the inside of the reservoir up to the top of its walls. If you are using our default housing we recommend a lower reservoir with a maximum height of 6 cm.
2A. Determine the maximum Z range (printable object height) for the reservoir you chose - the distance between the print base level (the level at which you start a print) to the maximum height of your build volume. You can do this by measuring the height of your wire mesh print base, and subtracting that from the height of your lower reservoir. For example - 6 cm (height of lower reservoir) subtract 1 cm (height of print base) = 5 cm (maximum Z range)
3A. Make sure that your sound card is set to maximum volume for the speaker.

Note: Some sound cards have a boost feature, audio effects, and microphone feedback. Ensure that these features are off.
4A. Mount the printer back onto the internal box by hooking the main hanger onto the internal box.
5A. With your safety glasses on, open the calibration software.
6A. Click "Add new calibration" then enter the height you determined in step 3.
7A. Select the "0.0" calibration and click "Delete current calibration".
8A. Place your lower reservoir directly underneath the printer, inside the internal housing. Lay the calibration grid on top of your lower reservoir so that it’s sitting at the height you determined in Step 2 (the height of your lower reservoir).
9A. Take the piece of extra elastic thread and tie a knot around the nut. You’ll use this as a miniature plumb bob to line the calibration grid up directly underneath the 2nd mirror on the printer.
10A. Take the nut with the string attached and lay it down on the center of the calibration grid. Take the untied end of thread and route it up and around the mirror frame so that the thread is hanging overtop of the frame in a "U" shape. The thread should hanging in line with the center of the mirror.
11A. Pull the untied end of the thread down until the nut is hanging about 1mm above the calibration grid, suspended from the second mirror.
12A. Move the calibration grid so that the center of the grid is lined up with the nut, but positioned about 5 mm behind it.
13A. Use the spring force adjustment tubes to align the laser beam to hit dead center of the calibration grid.
14A. Once you have the laser beam as close to center as you can get it, align the calibration grid so that the laser beam is hitting dead center on the grid.
15A. In the calibration application from the "Shape" pull down menu select "Xline". The printer should now be drawing a straight line back and forth along the X axis. Rotate the calibration grid so the laser path matches up with the gridlines.

Note: Move the shape back and forth between Center and Xline to assure that the calibration grid stays centered underneath the second mirror after it’s been moved.

Troubleshooting Tip: Due to the fact that the dynamic damper tab is a protruding and moving part, and that the static damper must be mounted in such close proximity for the dampening system to work, it can often be the source of malfunction if it’s not adjusted properly. If you’re experiencing issues here, it’s likely that the dynamic damper tab is running into the static damper and needs to be re-adjusted.
16A. In the calibration application from the "Shape" pull down menu select "Square". Your printer should now be attempting to draw a square on the calibration grid. It will most likely be quite warped. This is normal, and is what the calibration app is for.

Troubleshooting Tip: Depending on the size of square that the printer is drawing, a section of the square may appear to be missing. This is likely because the printer is attempting to draw a square too large and the laser beam is actually being blocked by the mirror frame for a portion of it's path. This can be fixed with calibration.
17A. Manipulate the values of the "shear" and "scale" tuning parameters to make the warped square a true square. Use the grid lines on the calibration grid as a reference to the correctness of the square. When finished, the 4 walls of the square should trace the lines on the calibration grid. You’ll need to make note of how large the square is, as you’ll have to re-create a square of the same size in a later step.

Tip: Start with shear, and finish with scale. It's generally a good idea to scale down (this will fix the issue of the laser path being blocked by the mirror frame).
18A. Measure the distance from the center to the edge of the square in millimeters and enter that in the "Max position" fields of the X and Y axis columns.

Note: The light grey grid lines on the calibration paper are 2mm apart, and the dark grid lines are 1 cm apart.
19A. Re-adjust the height of the calibration grid so that it is at the print base level (the height of your print base). The simplest way to do this is to put the calibration grid on top of your print base. If the calibration grid doesn’t fit inside your lower reservoir that is fine. Remove your lower reservoir from underneath the printer and place the calibration grid on top of the print base directly on the surface of your work area.
20A. Click the "Add new calibration" button and enter "0.0"
21A. In the calibration application from the "shape" pull down menu select "center"
22A. Align the calibration grid so that the laser beam is shining on the center point of the grid.
23A. In the calibration application from the "Shape" pull down menu select "Xline" and rotate the paper to line up on that axis.

Note: Move the shape back and forth between Center and Xline to assure that the calibration grid stays centered underneath the second mirror after it’s been moved.
24A. In the calibration application from the "Shape" pull down menu select "Square".
25A. Reduce the X and Y scale values in the “tuning parameters” section until the size of the square that the printer is drawing is equal to the size of the square that was drawn in step 17.

Note: Be sure that you don’t use the “size” field to adjust the size of the square as it’s a global variable and its value is not saved in each calibration file.
26A. Click save and save your calibration file under the name "tuning.dat"

Note: There is already a file named "tuning.dat" in the src directory. Overwrite it with your new file.

Part B - Calibrating the dripper

Description: This step allows the software to determine the height of the print surface in your tank. This process must be completed every time you physically alter the dripper or change the lower reservoir.

Note: The drip rate affects the size of the drips by as much as 30%. This is an issue we plan to account for in the software by measuring the time between each drip and using that in a formula to calculate the drip size. For now just be aware that it is still an issue. Another possible solution is a solenoid valve which governs a consistently fast drip speed by turning it on or off. Being that the Peachy Printer is a community project, feel free to get involved with the development of this feature by visiting the thread about it at 3Dprintboard.com.
1B. Ensure that your computer’s microphone levels are at 100% and no special effects or features are enabled (monitoring, etc).
2B. Remove the lower reservoir from underneath the printer and put the external housing and top plate over the printer.
3B. Fill your upper reservoir with salt water and place it on top of the printer. Hang the upper hose hanger of your drip feed on the rim of the upper reservoir. Ensure that the end of the hose is submerged in the saltwater, and that the clamp ring valve at the top of the drip feed is opened enough to allow the salt water to flow through the hose.
4B. Take the extra syringe and insert the nozzle into the bottom end of the drip feed. Pull the plunger all the way out, this should start the siphoning action.
5B. Hang the lower hose hanger on the rim of the lower reservoir. The drip feed should now be running. Adjust the clamp ring valve to stop the drip feed completely.
6B. Plug the audio jack that's wired to the drip feed into your computer's microphone jack.
7B. Launch the drip counter application.
A. Start the console / terminal / command prompt.
B. Change directory into the source folder for the application (where-you-saved it/PeachyToolChain/src).
C. Type python drip_counter.py and press Enter.
8B. Adjust the valve on your drip feed to start the dripping.

Note: As the drips fall, they must simultaneously make contact with both aluminum rods inside the syringe on your drip feed. If this is not happening, make sure the aluminum rods are aligned so that the upper rod is directly above the lower rod, and within a small enough distance that each drip can touch both rods for a fraction of time.
9B. You should have feedback in the console showing the drips as they occur.

Troubleshooting tip: If you can't see the drips being counted, a number of things could be going wrong. The aluminum rods in the drip feed may not be lined up properly, or the wires on the dripper could be hooked up incorrectly or have a bad connection. Check to ensure that these things are done correctly and if that doesn’t fix the problem, post in the forum for help. If you'd like, see if others need help too!
10B. Quit the application by pressing Ctrl-C.
11B. Close the valve on your drip feed so that the dripping stops.
12B. Make a mark 30 mm up from the surface of the salt water in the lower reservoir.
13B. Start the drip counter application again by typing python drip_counter.py and press Enter
14B. Open the valve so that it starts dripping at a rate of approximately one drip per second (you can just estimate this).
15B. Let the drip feed run until the surface level of the salt water in the lower reservoir is at the height of the mark you made in step 12. Note the total number of drips shown in the drip counter application.
16B. Calculate the total number of drips per mm by dividing the total number of drips by 10.
17B. Open the calibration application.
18B. Click "load" and select the "tuning.dat" calibration file you saved in Part A.
19B. Enter the drips per mm and click "save" to update this file.

Section 21 - Cure Time Calibration Print

Congratulations! You're about to do your first actual print :)

Description: In this step you'll find the ideal cure time (or laser speed). This is done by printing a corner and various speeds and then examining the print to determine the best cure time. If the laser moves too slowly, the resin gets exposed to too much light, resulting in a print that is overcured. Overcuring can cause a print to have very rough walls and sometimes even fail if the resin isn't able to break it’s surface tension quick enough. The ideal settings will result in a print that is still somewhat soft or squishy. You can then fully cure the printer at a later time by setting it out in sunlight, or by using a curing station. This process must be done each time that the laser is changed, or when using different resin formulas (stiff, flex, wiggle).

Note: Printing with PeachyJuice or MakerJuice Flex and Wiggle resins remains untested, so we recommend completing this section using PeachyJuice Stiff or MakerJuice SubG/SubG+ resin only. If you'd like to be a part of testing how the Peachy Printer performs with the Wiggle and Flex resins, there will be a subforum for that mission soon!

Note: This section has no images yet.
For this section you will need:
  • The Peachy Printer with all cables connected to your computer with software installed, and upper and lower reservoirs with a drip feed.
  • PeachyJuice or MakerJuice resin (Stiff or SubG)
  • Safety glasses
  • Black marker
  • Saltwater


Click to see an image of the parts labelled.

Safety Note: You must wear your safety glasses at all times Resin Warning: The resin is a mild skin irritant. To be safe while handling resin we recommend that you use latex gloves. Be sure not to rub your face or eyes after handling the resin. The resin can get quite hot when exposed to direct sunlight, so be extra careful to keep it away from your skin under sunlight. If the resin is cured too quickly, prints can actually shatter due to the pressure and tension created by the shrinking outer layer of resin. Once the resin is fully cured, it becomes inert and is no longer an irritant. Be sure to wash your fully cured print with soap and water before handling with your bare hands. Click here to read the full material safety data sheet.

1. Open the terminal and change directory into the source folder (src) in the Peachy Printer Tools folder, type python exposure_test.py and press Enter
This will generate gcode for your cure time calibration print.
2. Convert the gcode you just generated to a wav file from the command line by typing python gcode_wav_converter.py "tuning.dat" "exposure_test.gcode" "out.wav" "out.cue" and pressing Enter
3. Remove your upper reservoir from the top of the external housing, and then remove the external housing. Place your print base inside the lower reservoir, Add some salt water to the lower reservoir, then add a small amount of resin on top of the salt water (just enough to completely cover the surface) by slowly pouring it down the side wall of the container (similar to how a beer would be poured). Be sure that the surface level of the resin does not get above the wire mesh of your print base. Put the lower reservoir inside the internal housing making sure the laser beam is hitting the center of the print base.You can now place the external housing back on, and the upper reservoir back on top of the printer. Make sure that the drip feed still connects the two reservoirs.
4. Open the drip valve and let the surface level of the resin rise. Close the valve off when the surface level of the resin is just below the wire mesh print base.

Note: If the resin rises above the wire mesh print base, the print will not adhere to the base and your print will fail. This is because the laser light only cures approximately 0.1mm down into the resin.
5. Ensure that your microphone setting on the computer is set to 100% and your volume is also at 100%.
6. From the command line type python wav_player.py "Tuning.dat" "out.wav" "out.cue" and press Enter
7. Slowly turn on the drip valve and monitor the feedback on the screen. The print will start automatically once the software detects the first drip.
8. If you set the drip rate to fast, the software will give you the following warning: “Too fast:-------> X drips ahead”. If this happens re-adjust the clamp ring valve on the drip feed until the warning stops appearing.

Note: A print generally won't fail until the dripper is running 100-200 drips ahead. In fact, it doesn’t hurt to have the drip rate running 5-25 drips ahead at all times.
9. You are now printing! Watch and wait :)
10. The software will notify you when the print is completely. Stop the drip feed completely. Remove the print from the lower reservoir by picking up the print base with a pair of tweezers. Be careful not to expose it to UV light (sunlight, grow lights, tanning beds) until after you’ve completed all the steps in this section.

Safety Note: Be sure that you are wearing protective gloves when handling a fresh print. Once the print is fully cured, you can wash it thoroughly with soap and water, and then it is safe to handle with bare hands.
11. Set the print down and poke along it from top to bottom. You’ll notice that it’s cured hard on one end, and soft on the other. The ideal cure rate or laser speed will have taken place at the hardest (most cured) point that is still smooth. Make a mark at this point.
12. Measure the distance from the bottom of the print to the mark you made and subtract 3 mm from your measurement. To calculate your ideal laser speed in mm/second take your measurement, multiply it by 50, and add 100. For example, if your print is cured properly at a height of 10mm your calculation would be 10 * 50 + 100 = 600(mm/second).
13. Make note of this value as you will use it when generating your gcode. Congratulations on your first print!

Section 22 - Using Cura to Generate Gcode

Description: Gcode is what tells 3d printers where and when to move in order to print any given object. Unlike other 3D printers, the Peachy Printer is driven by an audio signal, however that audio signal is created using the data from gcode. The workflow is as follows:

3D model > .STL file > .gcode file > .gcode to .WAV > .WAV to printer

Cura is a free and open source program that generates gcode for 3D printers.

Note: We are working on getting gcode to come straight out of Blender, but until then we’ll have to use Cura.
For this section you will need:
  • A computer
  • An internet connection



    • Note: Cura is a third party utility for generating gcode for your model and is not supported by Peachy Printer.

1. Download Cura from http://software.ultimaker.com/
2. Install the application according to their instructions.
3. Start the application.
4. On the first time run wizard click Next
5. Select Other and click Next
6. Select Custom and click Next
7. Type in "Peachy Printer"
8. Type in the depth, width and height based on your lower reservoir size (40mm in all directions is standard)
9. Select bed center as 0,0,0
10. Click Finish. This will open Cura.
11. On the Basic tab in the print speed field enter the speed determined from the cure time calibration print in section 21 (The warning can be ignored).
12. On the advanced tab set all of the speed settings to the same value that you calculated from your cure time calibration print (the warnings can be ignored).
13. On the "Start/End Gcode" tab remove the contents in the text box from both options.
14. Cura is now setup for creating gcode for the Peachy Printer. In order to generate gcode, you will need a 3D object in the form of a .STL file. If help is needed to use Cura, refer to their help documents.

Section 23 - Your First Print

Description: Well done, you are ready to make your own print with the Peachy for the first time!

Note: There are no images for this section yet.
For this section you will need:
  • The Peachy Printer with all cables connected to your computer with software installed, and upper and lower reservoirs with a drip feed.
  • PeachyJuice or MakerJuice resin
  • Safety glasses
  • Wire mesh print base
  • Needle nose pliers or tweezers
  • Gcode to print


Recommendation: We strongly recommend that you chose a very simple object as your first print (a column, or a sphere). We also strongly recommend that you print small (under 4 cm) until you've ran a few successful prints. The reason for this is that if you do run into issues, you will find them and fix them much faster if your print only takes 5-10 minutes (as opposed to a print taking hours).

1. If you are continuing directly on from section 22 and still have your upper & lower reservoirs set up with a print base and resin, and the printer plugged into your computer then skip ahead to step 3. If not, start with step 2.
2. Remove your upper reservoir from the top of the external housing, and then remove the external housing. Place your print base inside the lower reservoir - make sure the laser beam is hitting the center of the print base. Add some salt water to the lower reservoir, then pour a small amount of resin on top of the salt water (just enough to completely cover the surface). Be sure that the surface level of the resin does not get above the wire mesh of your print base. You can now place the external housing back on, and the upper reservoir back on top of the printer. Make sure that the drip feed still connects the two reservoirs.
3. Open the terminal and change the directory to the source folder “peachy printer tools”, type python gcode_wav_converter.py "YourTuningFile.dat" "yourGcode.gcode" "out.wav" "out.cue" and press Enter
4. If you still have a full lower reservoir from the cure time calibration print you will need to syphon the salt water back into the upper reservoir. You can do this by simply lifting the lower reservoir above the upper reservoir. Once it's high enough, the syphon action will reverse, and flow into the upper reservoir.

Note: The surface level of the resin must get below the level of the print base before starting a new print. It is best to leave between 5-10mm of saltwater in the lower reservoir at all times. Make sure you don't suck any resin into the tubing of the drip feed as it will cure hard over time and clog your drip feed. Also, in order to prevent the drip feed housing from filling right up with water, ensure that when you're siphoning back into the upper reservoir the drip feed housing is completely upside down.
5. Open the drip valve and let the surface level of the resin rise. Close the valve off when the surface level of the resin is just below the wire mesh print base.

Note: If the resin rises above the wire mesh print base, the print will not adhere to the base and your print will fail.
6. Ensure that your microphone setting on the computer is set to 100% and your volume is also at 100%.
7. From the command line type python wav_player.py "tuning.dat" "out.wav" "out.cue" and press Enter
8. Slowly turn on the drip valve and monitor the feedback on the screen. The print will start automatically once the software detects the first drip.

Note: You may not see the laser turn on right away, this is normal. Drip slowly until the laser turns on.
9. If you set the drip rate to fast, the software will give you the following warning: "Too fast:-------> X drips ahead". If this happens re-adjust the clamp ring valve on the drip feed until the warning stops appearing.
10. You are now printing! Watch and wait :) If the feedback in the terminal tells you you're dripping too fast, adjust the drip rate accordingly.
11. The software will notify you when the print is complete. Remove the print from the lower reservoir by picking up the print base with a pair of tweezersor needle nosed pliers.
12. If your print needs to be cured more, you can do so by exposing it to UV light.
13. While wearing protective gloves, wash your print thoroughly with soap and warm water to remove any residue.

Section 24 - Troubleshooting & FAQ

Q: When printing the laser skips or jumps every time there is a drip.

A: Chances are that your microphone is feeding back into your speakers, look in your audio settings to disable this feature.
Q: When calibrating I see an open book shape rather than a square.

A: We have seen this happen with some computer / monitor power supplies, try using a cell phone charger (500ma or greater) or plugging in to a different power source.
More content coming soon.
